standards.header: Dietary services are provided by qualified dietitians.

details.header: A qualified dietitian supervises all aspects of dietary services in the hospital.
Services provided by the dietitian include, but are not limited to, the following:
details: Nutritional screening, assessment and reassessment of patients. Development of nutritional plan of care.
Highlighting “food-drug interaction” to clinical staff.
Making recommendations related to patient dietary needs.
Nil Per Os (NPO) monitoring.
Education of other health staff, patients, and families. Reviewing and updating the dietary manual.

details.header: Activities conducted by the dietician as part of the process of care is documented in the patient’s medical record.

standards.header: Patients identified to be at nutritional risk undergo comprehensive nutritional assessment.

details.header: Nutritional screening is conducted by qualified hospital staff (e.g., registered nurse) to determine the patient’s need for comprehensive nutritional assessment by a licensed dietitian.
The criteria used for nutritional screening during the initial assessment of patients are developed and approved by a qualified dietitian.
Comprehensive nutritional assessment is performed by a qualified dietitian for:
details: All patients identified at nutritional risk during the initial screening or assessment.
All patients identified at nutritional risk during the course of treatment.
All patients prescribed for a therapeutic diet.

details.header: Patients identified at nutritional risk are referred to a licensed dietitian for comprehensive nutritional assessment.
Nutritional assessment is preferably completed within twenty four hours of referral.
The comprehensive nutritional assessment is described in a policy and procedure that includes, but is not limited to, the following:
details: Height and weight chart for children. Body mass index (BMI) for adults.
Eating habits.
Food allergies.
Need for therapeutic diet.
Physical difficulties with eating and drinking and the need for any assisting devices.

details.header: The nutritional screening and assessment findings are documented in the patient’s medical record.

standards.header: Patients with nutritional disorders have the appropriate nutritional plans that meet their medical needs.

details.header: The dietitian, in collaboration with other clinical staff, develops an appropriate nutritional plan of care for patients with nutritional disorders.
Patients cultural and food preferences are respected to the extent possible.
The nutritional plan allows for consideration of:
details: Enteral tube feeding for malnourished or patients at risk of malnutrition and have inadequate oral intake and a functioning gastrointestinal tract.
Parenteral nutrition for patients with a non-functioning gastrointestinal tract.
Therapeutic diet prescribed for specific health conditions.

details.header: Patients are reassessed for response by the dietitian at regular intervals and adjustments are made accordingly.
The nutritional plan is documented in the patient’s medical record.

standards.header: The hospital has a current dietary manual.

details.header: There is a current dietary manual that is developed by the dietitian and other relevant staff.
The dietary manual is approved by the medical staff.
The dietary manual is used as the basis for diet orders and for planning therapeutic diets.
The dietary manual includes the following items:
details: Different types of diets used in the hospital.
Nutritional supplements used and how to use them.
Appropriate storage method for snacks and beverages.
Mealtimes and working hours of the kitchen.

details.header: The dietary manual is reviewed, revised, and updated at least every two years.
Copies of the dietary manual are readily available to all medical, nursing, and food services personnel.

standards.header: Therapeutic diets are provided when ordered.

details.header: Therapeutic diets are prescribed by the most responsible physician based on the patient’s needs.
Therapeutic diets are planned, prepared, and served with supervision or consultation from the dietitian.
The plan for a therapeutic diet must emphasize:
details: Total calories required.
Any restrictions.
The route and frequency of feeds.
When required, education about nutritional needs is provided to the patient and family upon discharge.

details.header: Discharge diets are prescribed by the most responsible physician in collaboration with the supervising dietitian.
Patients are educated on their nutritional needs upon discharge.
Education is documented in the patient’s medical record.

standards.header: The hospital provides safe food services.

details.header: Food preparation, handling, storage, and distribution is safe and guided by professional organizations standards and management systems (e.g., Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points, HACCP).
Food preparation, handling, storage, and distribution comply with laws and regulations.
